text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]\dim V = 5[/mathjaxinline]. Let [mathjaxinline]T: V\rightarrow V[/mathjaxinline] be a linear transformation. If we know that [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is not onto, what is the largest possible rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: Since [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is not onto, the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is some subspace of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] but cannot be [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] itself. Thus, the image must have dimension strictly less than 5.
To prove that it is possible for the dimension of the image to be 4, we give an example.

Then [mathjaxinline]\{ e_1;\ldots ; e_4\}[/mathjaxinline] is a linearly independent set that spans the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]; i.e., it is a basis of the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]. Thus the rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is 4.
